One word... Niobe... Joel has always talked about how he loves SmartClients... and ive been ramping up my Outlook skills, mostly with the .net framework... Niobe is a prototype project that allows managed, smart client add-ins to be developed for Microsoft Office Outlook 2003. Basically it is an abstraction of the current VBA, MAPI stuff and gives you a new managed object model to work with in .net. Anyway, yes this is a prototype (when was the last time you saw a prototype car on the lot), so I doubt it will ever make it to production, but Microsoft is watching this project, and it is fully usable (as far as I can tell). Anyway I just download it last night and just playing with it over my coffee break... pretty cool, ill post some source code to look at when i get home and can connect my laptop. I just created a small app that takes the xml contacts file from msn and adds them to my outlook contacts... not hard at all... Lastly, The guy that wrote it is pretty smart guy (Simon Guest, a program manager with Microsoft's .Net Enterprise Architecture Team.) so im not that worried about it crashing my outlook. ISAPI what? IHttpModule BABY!... So I was trying to implement an ISAPI filter last night.... not that easy.. you have to register it with IIS Metabase bla bla bla. In some cases you might need to do this in order to always have your code fire before anything else, but for my purposes IHTTPMODULE did the trick. IHTTPModule works wonderful for asp.net apps where you want logging to occur. I'm using it for something else.. but here it where it sits in case your wondering... Request --> IIS --> aspnet_isapi.dll --> HTTPApplication --> HTTPModule --> HTTPHandler anyway the basics to hook this up are. 1. create a class that implements IHttpModule 2. add a reference to your new handler 3. make a mod to your web config in system.web section: I was looking into this for my own purposes.. but hey.. why not have a logger that logs all requests to sql server. You could have it read from your config file and decide what eactions to take (ie: debug mode on etc...) anyway, if you want more information, email me urlLink here Miguel

We'll I ran into an interesting hickup when the machine kept telling me the web server didnt have .net framework installed on the web server. It's actually pretty easy to fix... Microsoft Windows XP [Version 5.1.2600] (C) Copyright 1985-2001 Microsoft Corp. C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework>cd v1.1.4322 C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v1.1.4322>aspnet_regiis /i Start installing ASP.NET (1.1.4322.0). Finished installing ASP.NET (1.1.4322.0). C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v1.1.4322> so there you have it.. once your in the right folder: C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v1.1.4322>aspnet_regiis /i Anyway, i just wanted to make note of that for myself If I have trouble again getting asp.net to start up on a web server. Happy Coding! Miguel

While it is very easy to write macros... (took about 20 min to write this thing, 5 minutes to fix Internet Explorer hanging all the freaking time).... I think ill stick with managed code. I can’t easily deploy this to anyone, and.. I don’t know.. I don’t see the reason to use this tool when I have vs.net, the best coder application ever created! ... Though I do see the value in having macro capabilities to do VERY small tasks, I don’t deem this to be a good long term solution by any stretch of the imagination. So.. Web Content Management and Internal Document Collaboration I’m going to be speaking at a large event next week in Winnipeg on Web Content Management, followed by a presentation on SharePoint Portal Server. I am extremely excited about both of these topics for a couple of reasons…. Coming from a web development background in the early 90’s, its amazing to see the change from using Mosaic to view extremely plain web sites, to what we have now, rich media packed web sites. Writing Basic programs was fun and dandy but the ability to write a site that would instantly be viewable by slightly over a million people just blew my mind. Passing around floppy disks of my latest version of chess in class was simply not fun anymore. I jumped on the web development band wagon instantly. However, the big down fall was the immediate loss I felt, of structure. HTML, Pearl, ASP, none really gave what I wanted until the rise of ASP.net. ASP.net 2.0 has some even better features, but I digress. Ok so now you have hundreds and thousands of companies writing web pages, web applications, content being translated from the original hard print documents created in quark, or PageMaker, to be placed on the web… STOP. If you stop to think how many times in a company the same thing is re-typed, formatted with the same style that hundreds of items before have been formatted, you might fall off your chair. And you would definitely be headed for the canvas if you realized how much money DAILY a large organization waist’s in the simple mundane task of converting data, promotional material, images, for the web world. Not only that, but what happens after a document is on the web? What happens if that server goes down? Typical world, you have the worlds worst server powering the company web site, and possibly some other tiny web applications that your company has decided will help there business. Server goes down, well, time to maybe go to the developers machine and get is local copies to stick on the web server, maybe install your applications again, etc etc. Truth of the matter is there is software out there that empowers organizations to tie in a database, and have web sites created at the click of a button. Not only that, but the data is saved in such a dynamic format, that you can literally choose to create web page, or a multimedia cd all from the same data. Anyway, I will write more later, but this is such a huge topic, and I haven’t even gotten to the content creation aspects where you can empower your business users to create there own content, right from the comfort of word. There’s some cool stuff out there, I love showing people that they can do all these great things today! Not tomorrow. Longhorn will be cool, but cool is already here!

Fathers Day Entry... The smartest man I have ever met in my entire life forwarded this email to me from someone that had sent it to him. I hope I can be half the man that he is one day. My Dad... please read... "People are often unreasonable, illogical, and self centred; Forgive them anyway. If you are kind, people may accuse you of selfish ulterior motives; Be kind anyway. If you are successful, you will win false friends, and some true enemies; Succeed anyway. If you are honest and frank, people may cheat you; Be honest and frank anyway. What you spend years building, someone could destroy overnight; Build anyway. If you find serenity and happiness, they may be jealous; Be happy anyway. The good you do today, people will often forget tomorrow; Do good anyway. Give the world the best you have, and it may never be enough; Give the world the best you've got anyway. You see, in the final analysis, it is between you and God; It was never between them and you anyway." I recently had to make one of the hardest, if not the hardest decision I have ever made in my entire (be it short) life. This passage has really helped and I have read it many times... I have always struggled with one thing, and that is to please everyone. Reality is you can’t, and it’s extremely tiring to try... Through the tough, hard decisions you make in life, you learn who your true friends and family are. The above passage mentions that it is between you and God... If you don’t believe in God, then this could be replaced with family, loved ones... Always put your best foot forward, and once you’re committed, take action. My parents came to Canada with 1,000 dollars. With that they have raised 3 kids, one of them myself. Though my father might have left everything in Chile, he came here so I could have a better life. I will always be greatfull for that. He might have left his degrees, training, everything in Chile, and though he might think he has not accomplished what he might have been able to, I think he accomplished more than he will ever know. Through Martial Arts, Day Care, he has talked to hundreds if not thousands of students, children, and has impacted all of there lives drastically. All you need is have one conversation with my father and you will know what I mean. Though he might not be doing what he studied to do, and engineer, through the lives he has touched he has honestly made this world a way better place to live for everyone. The people he has talked to will make a difference, and if one child that might have been hanging out with his friends, and gotten involved with drugs and gangs, murdereder someone, ends up going to school instead because my dad taught him or her Karate for free for years (with an occasional lecture for 3 hours after class) and gave them something to do while there parents were at a bar with friends, he has done more than I will ever do. I love you dad, Miguel
